title: Thursday, 13th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

hi

PM11:02am

But we'll come back to the Aramco Loophole

PM11:03am

First, a pic

11:02 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Nicky Morgan

PM11:03am

New chair of the Treasury select committee

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Also an FT columnist, of course

PM11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-9a66-93fb352ba1fe

PM11:04am

Feels like a good appointment to my untutored eye

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Actually, it's great in that it's not Rees-Mogg

PM11:04am

Guess she'll feature in future ML sessions

PM11:05am

But we most concentrate on things closer to markets right now

11:05 am
undefined
PM11:05am

So Bryce, this Aramco fudge

PM11:06am

Rule bending

11:05 am
BE11:06am

................... hm.

PM11:06am

Whatever we want to call it

BE11:06am

............................................... hm.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Feel i need to do a longer rant post about the slow decade of market quality

PM11:06am

Started with de-mutualisation

PM11:07am

And brought us to a situation like SNAP (Sell)

11:06 am
PM11:07am

And Aramco loopholes

PM11:07am

Where's the investor protection in all this

PM11:07am

Isn't that the main job of regulators and market supervisors?

11:07 am
PM11:07am

But I won't go on

PM11:08am

I havent been through the detail on this

BE11:08am

Look, I don't know. LSE Group is not a branch of the state so there's no particular, specific reason why it should act on any motive other than to improve the earnings of its shareholders.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

True

BE11:08am

Bending rules seems to be part of that.

BE11:08am

A structural part, given how often these alterations of convenience happen.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

New York worse than London of course, on this front

PM11:09am

Look at Alibaba

PM11:09am

And Snap (Sell)

11:09 am
PM11:10am

Any untended consequences here -- with Aramco??

PM11:10am

Or too early to say?

BE11:10am

The unintended consequences are immeasurable.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

I mean, there's the simple questions. Is Gazprom next, for instance?

PM11:11am

hehehe

PM11:11am

Oh, wait!

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The larger questions, I guess, relate to whether shareholders want to invest in a market where rules can be redrawn nearly on whim to keep happy a royal family who preside over a state where journalism is actively censored and there's antediluvian capital punishments are in place for crimes including drunkenness, adultery and such.

BE11:13am

But, as I say, LSE isn't a branch of government.

PM11:13am

Yeah, but the FCA IS

11:13 am
PM11:13am

And they are the ones "consulting' on bending the rules

PM11:13am

But let's move on

undefined
11:14 am
BE11:14am

(@Otter: I knew! someone would pick me up on that. I'm oddly pleased it was you.)

PM11:14am

Repeated requests for AstraZeneca already

PM11:14am

Over on the right

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Yeah, CEO's off. Maybe.

PM11:15am

THis story was in Haaretz first i think

BE11:15am

Immediately before the Mystic readout, maybe.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

http://www.haaretz...rael-news/1.801072

BE11:15am

It was Calcalist, I think, that had the story first.

PM11:15am

Pascal Soriot, the CEO of pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca, is the leading candidate to be the CEO of Israel’s Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.
The French-born Soriot, 58 has been serving as AstraZeneca's CEO since 2012. The Anglo-Swedish drug company has been active in Israel since 2009.  He is a veterinarian by training.
Teva chairman Sol Barer, who heads the search committee for the new CEO, and other Teva officials have met with Soriot and he has expressed his agreement to accept the job. 
Teva was left without a permanent CEO in February after Erez Vigodman stepped down, leaving new management to try to restore confidence in the world's biggest generic drugmaker after a series of missteps. Then chairman Yitzhak Peterburg replaced Vigodman on a temporary basis.
read more: http://www.haaretz...rael-news/1.801072

11:15 am
PM11:16am

Oh right, sorry

BE11:16am

Anyway, there's no official comment from either side.

PM11:17am

https://www.calcal...,L-3717093,00.html

11:17 am
BE11:17am

"This morning the speculation was denied by AstraZeneca," says SocGen, which I think it a confusion over what "no comment means".

PM11:18am

hehehe

PM11:18am

(Marketman - i will pester the techies)

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Because AZN is aware of its responsibilities to the market and denying something to SocGen analysts without denying it more publicly would be a fairly straightforward case of selective dissemination of price-sensitive information.

PM11:19am

And very price sensitive, in this case

BE11:19am

That never happens. To be clear.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

As we can see from the market reaction this morning

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,954, down 238.49 (-4.59%), High: 5,060, Low: 4,921, Volume: 1.76m
BE11:20am

Also, this denial SocGen's heard on the waves seems to match their house view.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We doubt there can be any truth in the speculation that Soriot, who has been the CEO of AstraZeneca for nearly five years and is only 58 years of age, is to stand down. Also, AZN has now finally reached its much publicized inflection point and would why he depart now (note: in 1Q17 he ‘allowed’ his protégé, Luke Miels, to leave to become the global head of Pharmaceuticals at GlaxoSmithKline). However, if Soriot did leave it would clearly be negative for sentiment in the short term. He is highly regarded by investors because of the impressive turnaround at AZN which he instituted. Also, in our view to extrapolate this to the Mystic trial is also implausible. This study is such a material event that AZN is duty bound to publish the results as soon as the trial is finished (i.e. the necessary number of events have taken place to satisfy statistical rigour). We continue to assign a 60% probability of success to Mystic in part because the phase 3 Pacific trial (and run with the same immunotherapy drug in a lower risk – i.e. less sick – population to Mystic) produced a positive headline result in 2Q17

PM11:21am

Why would he leave? Well, he's reportedly being offered a $20m signing bonus

BE11:22am

Yes, but ......

11:22 am
BE11:22am

AZN’s response to date has been the understandable “We do not comment on market rumours”. Meritable as Dr Soriot’s skills are, the reaction has more to do with the inferred implication for MYSTIC’s imminent outcome. There is not much useful we can add to this debate beyond the platitude that such a departure would clearly not be a positive signal, but we believe it to be extremely improbable on multiple grounds (the sheer incongruity of the opportunities, for starters). Indeed we note the Reuters report comes second hand from a local Israeli website named “Calcalist” and we offer to eat the proverbial hat if it materialises. We thus view the weakness as another good opportunity ahead of MYSTIC.

BE11:22am

That's Barclays.

BE11:23am

Best not to suggest eating things in response to news not happening, Barclays. You end up on Sky.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Can you name the analyst?

BE11:24am

I'll spare him that. He'll get a Twitter mob.

PM11:24am

True/fair enough

11:24 am
BE11:24am

The flipside of all this -- which I note mostly for completeness -- is the that, if Pascal goes, Pfizer comes back in for AstraZeneca.

PM11:24am

Well, maybe...

BE11:24am

That's BMO's take.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

If true, Mr. Soriot's departure could lower Street expectations for MYSTIC and AZ's IO pipeline. Moreover, we believe this increases the probability that AZ becomes an acquisition target for Pfizer again. We believe both are incrementally negative for BMY: 1) increased uncertainty with MYSTIC will lower expectations for BMY’s Opdivo + Yervoy; 2) AZ is probably a more attractive target for Pfizer, as opposed to BMY, particularly given that Pfizer has approached AZ before.

BE11:26am

The rest of the note is about Mystic cut-off points, which is fascinating for us oncology experts but I'll spare you, the general reader, the detail.

BE11:26am

Instead, have Kepler.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

We should flag that neither Teva nor AZN have responded to this report. Soriot has been mentioned as a CEO candidate elsewhere before – in 2014, when Sanofi were looking for a new CEO to replace Viehbacher, Soriot was reportedly approached, but was reported not to be interested. Soriot would be the second key AZN executive to depart This news follows the departure of Luke Miels, AZN’s head of European Pharma, who has departed AZN to rival GSK to head up their Pharmaceuticals division from September. There has been some recent controversy over Miels’ departure: the UK’s Times reported that Miels was threatened over his visa as punishment for leaving.

BE11:27am

Such a move would be a big change for Soriot: Teva is a leading generics company, so has a different business model to AZN. It’s also smaller than AZN (market cap is USD32bn vs. AZN’s USD85bn). Soriot would reportedly earn a c.USD11m salary with a USD15-20m signing bonus – he faced a shareholder revolt against his USD17m 2016 AZN package. It would also give Soriot the chance to play a key role in a Teva turnaround, with Teva looking for a CEO who can cut costs and restructure

BE11:28am

and Citi.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

[W]we cannot dismiss the Calcalist article given the track record of the Israeli press and the detailed disclosure of the compensation package. That said, we have significant trouble reconciling the timing of the potential departure pre-MYSTIC and Dr Soriot's skill set match with Teva. We also note that AZN's CEO was mooted to be talking to Sanofi's board following the departure of Chris Viebacher in October 2014. Our £60 NPV reflects risk adjusted 2022 combined durva and tremi revenues of $6.3b.

BE11:29am

From an AZN perspective, Dr Soriot's potential departure so close to the MYSTIC PFS read out (durva and tremi in 1st line NSCLC) will increase investor concern given now high consensus expectations for positive data scenarios. In reality, we doubt there is any rational read across given AZN remains blind to the data and Teva's executive search began likely in February 2017. We believe that AZN does not have the unblinded MYSTIC data in house as yet.

BE11:30am

I assume Dr Andrew Baum MD is right about the Mystic data not being with AZN yet -- though I'd also note that information alone seems quite price sensitive, given it's a binary outcome.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

In the event the CEO's departure is confirmed. Mene Pangalos, current head of AZN research and early development is the highest probability internal candidate, as well as Sean Bohen (CMO), in our view. We also suspect AZN's board has identified additional external candidates as part of the succession planning process.

BE11:30am

Is that enough drugs? I mean, we've no clarity on this, like everyone else.

PM11:30am

Sure, that's enough

11:30 am
undefined
PM11:31am

Deadcat In Carillion, finally

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 59.43, up 2.23 (+3.89%), High: 59.82, Low: 51.25, Volume: 19.85m
11:31 am
PM11:31am

Lovely column on this from you Bryce

PM11:31am

https://www.ft.com...-9a66-93fb352ba1fe

PM11:02am

Welcome to debased Markets Live

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Were you actually there?

BE11:31am

Hate writing columns for the paper. There's a requirement to sound like a I know what I'm talking about.

PM11:32am

Ditto

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Yeah, I was there. It was a lot less interesting than it sounds. But it was a handy excuse for a drop intro.

BE11:32am

....... so anyway, it's day four of the Carillion death spiral.

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 60.52, up 3.32 (+5.80%), High: 60.85, Low: 51.25, Volume: 20.29m
11:33 am
PM11:33am

Death spiral suspended, for now

BE11:33am

Oh, it's now spiraling upwards! Had to happen at some point, I guess.

PM11:33am

That's just over the past 30 mins

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Plumbed 52p earlier

BE11:34am

The catalyst, I can only assume, is that JP Morgan downgraded this morning from "overweight", 292p target.

BE11:34am

We see further risk to the downside, even at the current share price. On reflection, we previously did not adequately appreciate the sharp increase in receivables during 2016 and the high level of receivables vs peers. Our analysis suggests a further provision is possible and that current debt facilities may not be sufficient. We lower our 2017-19 profit forecasts by c.20% and cut our SOTP PT sharply to 64p, from 292p, rolling forward to Dec-18.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Yeah, on reflection that's probably right.

BE11:35am

Maybe the reflection could've come a bit earlier tho?

PM11:35am

Guess you are gonna spare that analyst's blushes as well

11:35 am
BE11:35am

While the recent KPMG review of Carillion’s accounting of contracts appears to have been thorough, we note that management used its judgment to determine final provisions. Our analysis (page 2-3) suggests a further (possibly material) provision may be necessary. In addition, we are not convinced Carillion’s current debt facilities will be sufficient to accommodate H2 peak gross debt. We struggle to see an elegant way out for Carillion, with our numbers indicating a possible equity raise of £532m (we consider a rights issue) needed to bring FY18e average ND/EBITDA to 1x. We are also not convinced that Carillion would represent a feasible target for a potential acquirer, given the scale of risk and liabilities.

BE11:36am

Genuinely, it's a painful read.

BE11:36am

We overlooked the size of receivables and their rapid growth in H2 2016. We also overlooked the probable drivers behind the rapid growth of the reverse factoring scheme. More generally, we likely should have put more emphasis on the numbers themselves, rather than the circumstances surrounding them.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Yeah.

PM11:37am

sheesh

BE11:37am

While we believe further risk is likely to the downside, we are opting
for a Neutral in light of material uncertainty on many issues, including future provisions, the decision and ability to raise equity, and the possibility of being acquired.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

I'm going to stop now. I'm getting shame by proxy. Instead, have some Jefferies.

BE11:39am

The combined (average) debt position and pension deficit is expected to be c.£1.3bn in FY17; we expect little improvement in CY18. Contract unwinds as we exit construction market, combined with lower utilisation of the early repayment facility, will offset any working capital efficiencies, and further write-downs remain a meaningful risk, in our view. Assuming bond rates remain as they are the pension deficit should reduce in-line with the repayment schedule, however (c. £50m p.a.).

BE11:39am

Our new estimates drive a revised price target of 80p, broadly inline with the current share price. However, realistically we see no future for Carillion without a rights issue of at least £500m as we believe the group will find it increasingly difficult to win Support Services work with the balance sheet in its current state

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Note, though, it's just not an equity story any more.

BE11:40am

EV of ~£1.1bn of which £250m is the equity.

BE11:40am

Which ignores the £587m pension liability, wrongly.

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Here's some reading material for Carillion's remaining management

PM11:41am

http://www.bankofe...3/qb93q1110115.pdf

BE11:42am

From our perspective, there's simply no way to value this thing not when you're you're getting 8% on Carillion two-year debt. Leave it to the bulletin board types to talk about shakeouts, resistance points and market makers wanting your stock.

11:42 am
undefined
BE11:42am

What else, then?

PM11:43am

Game?

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Ha!

BE11:43am

Hahahahaha!

BE11:43am

A-hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha!

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Omg smile Ashsley

Game Digital PLC (GMD:LSE): Last: 26.44, up 2.19 (+9.02%), High: 28.00, Low: 25.44, Volume: 2.33m
BE11:44am

This is just ludicrous!

11:44 am
PM11:44am

They are welcoming Sports Direct as strategic partners

PM11:44am

https://www.invest...1707130701019228K/

BE11:44am

"Strategic partners", sure.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Fits completely with Debenhams, JD Sports, Findel & French Connection

BE11:45am

Strategic partnership. Why not. We're getting a reasonable insight on how Ashley negotiates partnerships in the High Court right now.

BE11:46am

All the evidence suggests he uses Sports Direct cash to punt on random retailers as a kind of distressed high street hedge fund.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

The partnership with Debenhams has so far delivered a few rather awkward concessions dropped into the stores and the stock sinking to a record low.

BE11:48am

What's he up to? Look, the sellside are paid to polish this kind of stuff with fallacious logic, and polish is what they do.

BE11:48am

Here's Canaccord.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

We think that there are various areas in which GAME could benefit from working with Sports Direct. There could be some scope for GAME concessions in Sports Direct (av store size 11,000sq ft), albeit this would be limited to the larger stores (GAME is currently trialling with WH Smith). Collaborations around games such as FIFA would make sense. There could also be opportunities around e-sports and Insomnia. We think there should be a reasonable overlap in terms of customer demographic.

BE11:49am

"opportunities around e-sports" ... sure, because it's important what trainers you wear when playing Fifa 17.

BE11:50am

With Elliot holding c. 43%, anything more than a strategic stake on Sports Direct's part is clearly contingent on Elliot's position. There is also an asset backed loan (not currently being utilised) with change of control clauses attached to it.
As we highlighted in our note following the 30 June trading update, while it is difficult to plot the trajectory of any recovery in trading (which is subject to to the product cycle/ supply), there are assets within GAME that we believe could support longer-term growth through the gaming cycle. Constructive support from Sports Direct could help to realise this. Sports Direct is due to report prelims on 20 July, when we may have an opportunity to learn more of its intentions.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

(@Boncoeur: yup. He also lost it.)

PM11:51am

Quite a bit of polishing there

BE11:51am

Liberum also mention e-sports and Insomnia, in the manner of firm that's had a call from a flack.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

We see a number of reasons how GAME and SPD can gain from a closer working relationship but it is surely the similar customer demographics that must be the key draw card here. The strategic play is not likely to have any concern with reference to the console cycle but rather growth in e-sports, Insomnia events and in-store gaming.

BE11:51am

Taking a long-term view as we consider the following strategic thoughts. In our view this is a deal that makes a lot of sense:

The favorable customer demographic of GAME and what is likely to be a strong overlap with the Sports Direct customer base. At at IPO (June 2014), 96% of GAME's customers were under 55 years old. 50% were between 18-35 and the average customer visited stores c.10 times a year;
GAME takes dominant market shares of 29% and 39% in the UK and Spanish gaming markets respectively. The opportunity in Spain is interesting, where GAME has around 270 stores and Sports Direct has just two. Growing its business in the larger European markets has proved tricky for Sports Direct in the past and GAME could help provide a platform here;

We believe the rapid growth of eSports, while offering a key long-term opportunity for GAME, also likely provides an attractive angle for Sports Direct as sportswear and equipment retailer. The UK's eSports industry is relatively nascent, with around 6.5m UK eSports participants (NewZoo), vs. 256m worldwide, and this is expected to reach c.350m within 3 years. Interestingly in the US there are significant and growing interest in the eSports market with high profile deals involving professional sports companies and personalities, signalling to us there is a long term opportunity here.

Events provide customer reach: On the Events side of the business, GAME now runs the 2 major Insomnia gaming events in the UK which attract total footfall of c.100,000. This could present merchandising opportunities for Sports Direct;

The store base and co-location opportunity is also significant for both companies, in our view. . The successful trial of GAME's in-store gaming arenas ('BELONG') and the overlap in the customer base and suggests that these arena's could be an attractive addition within a Sports Direct store, of which there c.450 in the UK.GAME has an average remaining lease length of c.1-2 years across its estate, giving significant flexibility in own store base. We do not know if this will form part of the strategy but there encouraging precedent within UK retail such as Dixons Carphone 3-in-1 stores, and Sainsbury's/Agros mergers.

BE11:51am

That kind of thing.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Censored

Isen, Robert Gleckman, Brian Heepke, Dennis J. Verderosa, Emin Cohen, Sergio Ramirez, and Ashley Antos, Defendants, and Hermann Matz, Joseph Matz, Brittney Ballestas, Melissa Kurtzke, Janine Acosta, Type A Partners, Inc., Strategic Capital Markets, Inc., Marketbyte LLC, Snap or Tap Productions, LLC, Dacona Financial LLC, TradeMastersPro.com, Inc., MyStreetResearch.com, Inc., Revolving Ventures LLC, TradeMasters Consulting, Inc., Big Little Consulting, Inc., BCBall, Inc., Gabron Transport Corp., PTP Construction Corp., Terryville Systems, Inc., MKKMMKKM, Inc., Trek Partners LLC, RKRG, INC., Price Point Consulting, Inc., DJV Enterprises, Inc., Leecorp, Inc., Soccerserge, Inc., and Antos, Inc., Relief Defendants

PM11:53am

PM11:53am

During these calls, victims were allegedly harassed and threatened by sales personnel. When one victim complained about his losses, a sales representative allegedly said, "I am tired of hearing from you. Do you have any rope at home? If so tie a knot and hang yourself or get a gun and blow your head off."

11:54 am
PM11:54am

Full complain is here

PM11:54am

www.sec.gov/litiga...2017/comp23878.pdf

undefined
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Just catching up with the ROTR .........

BE11:54am

N Brown mentioned.

N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 295.70, down 8.8 (-2.89%), High: 296.70, Low: 274.70, Volume: 1.34m
11:55 am
BE11:56am

Hey, seems if you sell people credit on terms that hugely advantage you and disadvantage them, those people sometimes want some money back.

BE11:56am

This seems to be a theme that comes up quite a lot, though not so much as anyone ever cares about it quarter by quarter.

BE11:57am

N Brown compensation payments bumped up by £35-40m.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Taking the total to £70m.

BE11:57am

"product insurance" this time.

BE11:57am

Here's Peel Hunt with the detail.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Having already paid out compensation for sales of
its own credit insurance products of up to £20m, N Brown has announced further exceptional costs of £35-40m relating to the sale of third-party general insurance customers. This relates to product protection, the bulk of which was sold to protect clothing sales over the period from 2006-14. The previous scale of the PPI claims had grown to be much greater than the initial assessment. In this case, the burden of proof is much easier; if the customer paid for the product, then they are likely to be compensated. Therefore, there is a greater degree of confidence that the £35-40m is a prudent assessment of the overall liability, which may well reduce depending on potential mitigation, not least the potential liability of the insurance product creator/underwriter.

BE11:59am

N Brown’s credit book of £500m+ sits on the balance sheet; the core business is not heavily geared. However, we forecast free cash flow before dividends of c£40m pa; management is unlikely to jeopardise dividend payments, so we expect this claim to be paid from free cash, albeit that may well require N Brown to take this into account when it comes to its thoughts on refinancing and covenant levels. The current facility runs to 2020; an early change looks likely.

BE12:00pm

This is post the FCA request in February on whether insurance policies were priced fairly.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And is something we've talked about previously with reference to the likes of Homeserve.

HomeServe PLC (HSV:LSE): Last: 716.00, up 0.5 (+0.07%), High: 726.00, Low: 714.00, Volume: 37.48k
